awd_titl_txt: Building a Platform of Impact-Energy Absorbing Materials: How Molecular Manipulations Translate into Macroscopic Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

A unique property of polymers is their ability to absorb mechanical energy during impact events by transferring that energy into molecular motions of the individual polymer chains.  This project is focused on studying the fundamental materials properties for a platform of energy-absorbing polymers and developing a toolbox to introduce molecular mechanisms to increase toughness, energy dissipation, and the potential for nanoscale self-healing that will increase the lifespan of the material. This platform is based on polymer network materials called "thiol-ene network thermosets". They can be made through chemistry that offers fast reaction times and highly homogeneous networks, like a chain-link fence, resulting in high energy absorption capacity. Previous work in the Savin group has demonstrated the ability to make molecular-level changes in the network and have this translate into macroscopic changes in the physical properties of the materials.  These changes can be done in a modular way using facile chemistry.  The resulting materials have applications in sound damping, shatterproof coatings, personal protective equipment (e.g., mouthguards and multi-impact foams), and ballistics protection.  Advances in scientific discovery will be incorporated into the education and training of students, integrating a broad range of disciplines including chemistry, physics, biochemistry, and polymer science.  Group members will gain a comprehensive understanding of polymers in many areas of synthesis, characterization, morphology, scattering and rheology, from both a fundamental and an applied standpoint.  This multidisciplinary approach is beneficial not only for education, but also to produce well-rounded graduates who are attractive to a variety of employers in both academic and industrial settings. Diversity and involvement in K-5 elementary science outreach are also strongly emphasized. 



TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The objective of this research is to study the fundamental materials properties for a platform of energy absorbing polymers based on thiol-ene network (TEN) thermosets. Previous research on TENs has shown the ability to make molecular-level manipulations through chemistry and have this translate to changes in macroscopic performance and function. The goal of this research is to exploit advances in TEN modification to synthesize new monomers where we introduce mechanisms to increase toughness, as well as the potential for self-healing that will ultimately increase the life span of the material. This will be done for both slab (Aim 1) and foam (Aim 2) materials. In the proposed research, we will introduce these molecular-level mechanisms for energy dissipation and toughness through dynamic-covalent sacrificial, mechanochemical linkages, and incorporation of photo-responsive, liquid crystalline azobenzene substituents. Building a toolbox of network modifications will allow us to discover materials that have the potential to transform the field of energy-absorbing materials by expanding functionality. The modified TEN materials platform that will be developed in this proposal is completely modular and can be applied to applications such as personal protective equipment, curable coatings, ballistics protection, dental restoratives, and polymer composite materials. Successful completion of the proposed research will yield a platform of materials with improved impact-energy absorption properties, as well as an understanding of how molecular design and manipulation translates into dynamics and macroscopic function.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Building a Platform of Impact-Energy Absorbing Materials:

How Molecular Manipulations Translate into Macroscopic Properties

 

The objective of this proposal was to develop a class of energy-absorbing materials that can be used in personal protective equipment (PPE) such as in mouthguards. The materials platform is based on combining thiol and ene-containing resins, which are known to link together to form networks (called ?thiol-ene? networks) that are very homogeneous. On a molecular level, thiol-ene networks have a similar structure to a chain-link fence. Homogeneity manifests itself by having the spacing between the links the same for all links and having the mesh size be the same throughout the network. However, homogeneous networks tend to tear very easily and are not tough. The strength and toughness of the thiol-ene networks can be increased by introducing a ternary component into the resin mixture. The general idea is that the ternary component produces sacrificial linkages in the network that can break during the impact event and then reform after, which leaves the primary thiol and ene linkages intact.

 

Intellectual Merit:

In this project, there were three classes of ternary components studied: (1) photo-responsive liquid crystals, (2) dynamic bonds, and (3) molecules that change color during mechanical deformation. The greatest success was demonstrated using photo-responsive liquid crystals, and the attached Figure shows an exemplary result. In this material, azobenzene is incorporated into the primary network, and the glass transition temperature (Tg) (a material property used to determine the temperature at which a material will show the best energy-absorbing properties) is measured as a function of the amount of azobenzene added to the thiol-ene resin mixture. The inset in the upper left shows a schematic of the network, where the orange groups represent azobenzene units in the blue thiol-ene matrix. The inset in the lower right shows optical images of the networks where the deep orange color of the azobenzene increases with increasing concentration. For reference, these networks have dimensions (length/width/height) of around 3 cm/1 cm/0.5 cm. From the figure, it is shown that Tg increases with increasing azobenzene content. The blue points correspond to networks prior to post-processing with heat. The blue line represents the predicted Tg. In this case, the samples exhibit a Tg below the prediction due to unincorporated resin. In contrast, the orange points represent the networks post processing and the orange line represents the predicted Tg.. There are two important results that were determined. First, the Tg as a function of composition spans over 90 K, so the energy-absorbing properties for this system can be tuned over a wide range of use conditions. Second, the Tg of the networks exceeds the predicted value. This occurs because the azobenzene units assemble into liquid crystal domains that serve as additional anchoring points in the network. This is conclusion supported by additional thermal analysis techniques that show the liquid crystal melting occurs at around 360 K. These materials have applications as PPE or potentially as shape-memory materials.

 

Broader Impacts:

Mouthguards are a ubiquitous form of PPE used to mitigate concussive injuries and the associated brain trauma by reducing the amount of force transmitted to the brain during an impact event to the mouth and jaw. This research program demonstrates how molecular manipulations to network structure translate into macroscopic performance and function for energy-absorbing materials that can be used to produce mouthguards. Half of the participants in the project came from underrepresented groups, and four of the undergraduate participants have matriculated into PhD programs in chemistry and chemical engineering. From a training standpoint, this project spans many technical areas: small-molecule synthesis, photo/thermal polymerizations, thermoset formation, and thermomechanical properties. As such, this broad research approach spans many disciplines and establishes an extensive training platform for students and other participants. Finally, the PI and students participated in a number of education and community outreach activities prior to COVID. These included teaching science concepts and performing science experiments with elementary students through the ?You are a Scientist!? program. After COVID, some aspects of the outreach program were implemented virtually.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Brent S Sumerlin

Image
  • Glass transition temperature vs. azobenzene composition for ternary thiol-ene networks. (Left top inset) Schematic of the network, where the orange groups represent azobenzene units in the blue thiol-ene matrix. (Right bottom inset)
    Daniel Savin
    Public Domain
    Brent S Sumerlin
    Figure 1
